Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Resource and Stress Processes Underlying Economic Disparities in Early School Success

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to pinpoint key processes through which income inequality influences children's academic success. Children from wealthier families have much better academic skills than do children from economically disadvantaged families, and such disparities interfere with disadvantaged children's educational success, thereby inhibiting broad preparation for 21st century jobs and American economic success. To benefit society, this study will facilitate children's preparation for the future by revealing the most impactful processes driving inequality in children's academic skills. It will do so by building and testing a conceptual framework for understanding the processes that contribute to gaps in the academic skills of economically advantaged versus disadvantaged children. The study has important implications for improving the lives of American children and families by identifying targets for interventions and policies that could improve the life chances of economically disadvantaged children and stem growing inequalities in school success.

This study will expand extant knowledge of how economic factors influence children's early learning and academic skills. Specific objectives are (1) to create, test, and refine a comprehensive model of the important contextual forces that transmit income inequality to young children's academic skills; (2) to combine data from multiple national data sources using pioneering geographic mapping technologies; and (3) to use cutting-edge analytic techniques to determine how key family, school, and neighborhood processes are involved in the relationship between economic inequality and children's differing academic skills. The project will combine a broad array of national administrative data sources with longitudinal survey and assessment data on approximately 11,000 children followed from infancy through kindergarten and 18,000 children followed from kindergarten through 5th grade. Econometric statistical analyses will simultaneously test home, school, and neighborhood processes to delineate significant factors that influence the development of children's skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

Research has delineated large income disparities in the development of key academic competencies-- cognitive, language, and attention skills?that are essential for the successful transition to school and that drive later educational achievement and attainment. Knowledge of the processes contributing to these growing gaps is surprisingly limited and piecemeal, lacking a comprehensive overarching conceptual framework.  In this project, we combined leading theories and a broad array of data sources to develop and test a comprehensive, multi-level model of processes driving income-achievement gaps. In doing so, we delineated fundamental family and neighborhood processes through which income inequality is translated to children?s early learning and skills in the current generation of US children. We drew data from two leading panel datasets (ECLS-B, ECLS-K 2011) to document children?s development from infancy through fifth grade. Information on resource and stress processes were drawn from the panel datasets as well as from a broad array of national administrative data sources, leading to an innovative and expansive view of proximal processes linking income to children?s development. Analyses incorporated innovative mapping technologies and careful, multistage descriptive, econometric, and growth modeling strategies to address concerns of selection bias.

Intellectual Merits

This project advanced understanding of ecological models by considering how processes unfold across multiple nested levels of context simultaneously. In particular, it tested how community and family contexts jointly shape children?s development and tested how community characteristics operate through family processes.  Additionally, it advanced poverty research by integrating resource and stress theories and testing resource and stress processes at both family and neighborhood levels across early development. This study has been one of the first to shed light on developmental differences in how community and family contexts shape children?s learning and development.  A central methodological contribution of this study is the use of GIS mapping techniques to rigorously map and validate availability of salient neighborhood resources and the prevalence of neighborhood stressors. Moreover, the merging of multiple datasets and attention to individual differences provide unique methodological advances to the fields of poverty and child development. Synthesizing findings across two samples, one focused on early childhood and the other focused on the elementary school years, our results reveal that in early childhood community contexts tend to relate to children?s development through connections with parenting practices. By the time children age into middle childhood, direct linkages emerge between community resources and stressors and children?s academic, cognitive, and psychosocial development. 

Broader Impacts

On a practical level, this study has important implications for improving the lives of economically disadvantaged American children and families by identifying targets for experimentally-manipulated interventions and policy efforts which seek to improve the skills and life chances of economically disadvantaged children and stem growing inequalities in school success. Across a series of studies, we found that family income had small to medium associations with heightened access to community resources and lower exposure to community stressors. These associations partially explained income gaps in children?s academic skills, executive functions, and externalizing problems. Many of these mediated relationships operated through parenting, including cognitive stimulation, parental warmth, and harsh discipline. Results have implications for researchers and practitioners focused on narrowing economic skills gaps as well as housing and community planning efforts designed to foster children?s positive development.  Broad dissemination of results expand broader impacts to academic, policy, and community audiences. Through our pre- and post-doctoral training and teaching plans, this study provided opportunities to educate and to cultivate the next generation of researchers examining how poverty and place intersect to shape child development.
